Not long ago, Mehl's office commissioned a report to see how well the smog check program was doing.
The answer?
Not so great.
One in five older cars failed a roadside smog test, the same test that many of them had passed just months before.
Somehow, smoggy, polluting cars were managing to get through the smog test in droves.

How bad is that?
Bad enough that her office decided to give the system an overhaul, starting with the smog shops.

Here, California is a bit special.
Some states send drivers to centralized government-run shops to take the smog test.

But with so many cars, California has had to privatize its program, relying on shops like this one, Smog and Go in Sacramento, where owner Jack Williams says sometimes a customer will give him a little nudge.
Very occasionally there will be a customer that does try to make an approach that they would be willing to pay to have a vehicle pass.
Which of course he refuses to do.
No, we do the test the way that the test needs to be run.

Within a few months, the bureau accused about 200 smog shops of defrauding the test.
Many were fined, some were shut down in days.
But car owners play a part in this, too.
Some cars are so old, so dirty, that they really shouldn't be on the road at all.
In other cases, all it would take to turn a dirty car into a relatively clean one is a cheap fix, a hundred bucks, even.
Instead, some drivers try and squeak by.
They'll do things to their car like change the oil right before they go in for their test, what we call super heat their car.
